_prev_prog_3.Description: Process Safety Information (68.65) - The process is 46,350 pounds of ammonia. The MSDS for ammonia is available to all employees associated with the process. The process is not only designed in compliance with good engineering practices and with Federal and state regulations, it is also maintained within safe operating ranges.                                                                                                   Process Hazard Analysis (68.67) - The process hazard analysis (PHA) for Advanced Technical Ceramics Company's Chattanooga, TN facility indicates that the facility was properly designed and is following procedures which minimize the probability of a release. The elements of the PHA include those hazardsassociated with the chemicals use, equipment malfunctions, human errors that may result in an accidental release, safeguards to prevent accidental releases, and detection and monitoring steps. The PHA is performed by qualified personnel acknowledgeable in the process and in the PHA methodology.                                                                                          Operating Procedures (68.69) - The process is operated by trained personnel using safe operating practices. Specifically, there are written operating procedures for each operating phase including initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, normal shutdown, startup, correction of deviations and equipment inspections. These written operating procedures are regurlary reviewed and are readily accessible to the operators.                                                                                                  Training (68.71) - All employees presently operating or assigned to the process have been trained or tested in the skills and duties necessary to safely operate the process. Futhermore, all employees who are newly assigned to the process are thoroughly trained and tested proficient before operating the process. A list of the trained employees is maintained. Refresher training is provided at least every three years, or more frequently if needed to maintain safe operating practices.                                                                                                Mechanical Integrity (68.73) - All process equipment is properly inspected and serviced either by trained employees or maintenance contractors. Any maintenance contractor shall ensure that each contract employee is properly trained in the maintenance procedures to be performed. All identified equipment deficiences are corrected in a safe and timely manner.                                                                                              Management of Change (68.75) - Written procedures are in place to manage process changes, including changes in equipment and procedures. All personnel affected by these changes are promptly informed of the changes and trained to deal with the modification.                                                                                                         Pre-start-up Review (68.77) - Whenever a change is made to the process necessitating a change in the process safety information, Advanced Technical Ceramics Company, confirms the  completeness of the Prevention Program revision. This includes confirming that a PHA has been performed for the correctly installed equipment, procedures are in place for operations, maintenance, and emergency response, and the employees trained in the new procedures.                                                                                                            Compliance Audits (68.79) - The procedures and practices of the RMP Prevention Program for the process at Advanced Technical Ceramics Company, TN facility comply with the requirements of 40 CFR 68 and are currently being followed. Compliance audits are conducted at least every three years to determine if current procedures are appropriate and being followed. The two most recent complaince audits are available.                                                                                                   Incident Investigation (68.81) - All incidents which resulted in or may have resulted in a catastrophic release are investigated in order to correct any safety deficiencies that have the potential to result in a future release. Investigations begin less that 48 hours after the occurrence of the incident. The findings of the investigation are reviewed with all affected personnel and corrective action is taken to prevent future release. The summaries of all the incident investigations from the past five years are available.                                                                                                    Employee Participation (68.83) - Advanced Technical Ceramics Company's employees have participated in the development of the PHA, operating and maintenance procedures. All employees are made aware of the hazards associated with the process, as well as the effort to assess and minimize the probability and effect of a release.                                                                                                             Hot Work Permit ( 68.85) - Advanced Technical Ceramics Company has in place procedures to safely conduct hot work. These include procedures for initiation, hot work area review, safe hot work methods, and fire watches.                                                                                                                 Contractors (68.87) - In order to minimize the risk associated with the use of contractors on the process, Advanced Technical Ceramics Company reviews the safety history of each potential contractor. All contractors working on the process are informed of the process hazards and emergency procedures. Procedures are in place to limit and control contractor movement on site.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

Advanced Technical Ceramics-Chattanooga, TN



Advanced Technical Ceramics Company (AdTech Ceramics) is an ISO9001:2008 and AS9100D manufacturer of multilayer co-fired ceramics electronic packages.  Processes revolve around 50 plus years of experience in material science, engineering, design, tooling and manufacturing of multilayer ceramics.  AdTech Ceramics provides High Temperature Co-fired Ceramic (HTCC), Ceramic Feedthroughs, Multi Layer Aluminum Nitride (AlN), Chemical Metal Milling, and Injection Molded Ceramics to the military, aerospace, medical, energy, and other high reliability applications industries.



System Overview



AdTech Ceramics has a process by which anhydrous ammonia is "dissociated", or broken down, into its elemental components, nitrogen and hydrogen.  Saturated anhydrous ammonia vapor is piped to dissociator units that heat the ammonia vapor to 1750?F, thereby facilitating separation of the NH3 molecule into its component parts, nitrogen (N2) and hydrogen (H2) gases.  This dissociated ammonia (DA) gas is used as process gas for firing kilns and furnaces in a controlled reducing atmosphere free of oxidation.  Anhydrous ammonia is supplied by tanker truck through a liquid filled connection.   Emergency shut-off valves are provided at both the liquid fill and vapor return lines to allow quick shut-off of liquid and vapor flow in the event of an accidental pull-away of a truck or hose rupture.  Ammonia is stored in a liquid state in equilibrium with its vapor at saturation conditions in a pressurized vessel.  The vessel is maintained at approximately 125 psig by an electric vaporizer controlled by pressure switches modulating the heat input to the ammonia vaporizer.



Anhydrous Ammonia Storage Vessel



Ammonia storage includes a 12,000-gallon stationary, horizontal, cylindrical pressure vessel for storing liquefied anhydrous ammonia.  The storage vessel is sized to provide approximately 90 days of continuous supply of diss

ociated ammonia gas before requiring refilling.  The vessel is mechanically rated for a maximum allowable working pressure of 250 psig at 125?F.  The ammonia storage vessel temperature is monitored through a local indicator.  The liquid level in the vessel is monitored through a local gauge as well as an electronic telemetry unit.  An alert system including an audible alarm is installed for leak detection and out-of-tolerance pressure conditions.  The ammonia tank pressure is indicated through a local gauge.  The tank is equipped with two (2) sets of dual pressure relief valves set at 250 psig atop 3-way valves; excess flow valves at all fluid flow nozzles; and thermal relief valves set at 350 psig on associated liquid ammonia lines.



Ammonia  Dissociators



Anhydrous ammonia vapor is piped from the top of the storage tank at 125 psig and is reduced to 40 psig to provide constant pressure feed to the dissociator vessels.  At each of the three (3) dissociator vessels the NH3 vapor is again reduced to 12 psig for introduction into the pre-heater.  NH3 vapor is then piped into the catalyst chamber and heated to approximately 1750?F.  The dissociated ammonia gas (DA) is then piped into the plant for use in the kilns and furnaces as process gas. Atop each dissociator vessel piping is a Kunkle pressure relief valve set at 15 psig.





AdTech Ceramics has diligently developed and implemented a comprehensive Risk Management Program, assessing the hazards associated with the process, as well as implementing procedures which minimize the probability and severity of an ammonia release.  The facility has not had an accident in the past five years involving ammonia that caused deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or shelterings in place. An OSHA Process Safety Management Program is currently implemented for the ammonia process. Futhermore, the facility complies with the EPA's accident prevention rule and all applicable state and local codes and re

gulations.  In the event of an emergency involving the ammonia process, it is our policy to notify the Chattanooga Fire Department.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    

Risk Management Plan (RMP) and Process Safety Management (PSM)



AdTech Ceramics recognizes that people are its most vital resource and their safety and health is one of our principal responsibilities.  AdTech Ceramics will strive to provide a safe and healthy working environment and to avoid adverse impact and injury to the environment and the communities in which we do business.  AdTech utilizes a Risk Management Plan (RMP) and Process Safety Management (PSM) Program to provide guidelines for preventing and/or minimizing the consequences of catastrophic releases of toxic, reactive, flammable, or explosive chemicals.  In general terms, the RMP protects the health and safety of environment and the community, and the PSM program protects the on-site employees.



Items that are addressed in the RMP/PSM:



An Emergency Response Plan has been developed to address a broad spectrum of emergency scenarios and contingent responses.  



Offsite Consequence Analysis of worst case and an alternative case release scenarios where air dispersion models and release parameters are evaluated to determine off-site impacts and affected populations. 



A management system is in place to implement and manage the RMP/PSM procedures.  The qualified person is responsible for coordinating with and keeping local authorities informed of changes that affect the RMP/PSM as part of Tier II Emergency Response Information.



The Process Safety Management program provides a safe and healthful work environment for the facility employees and contractors by performing a process hazard analysis.  A process hazard analysis is

an organized and systematic effort to identify and analyze the significance of potential hazards associated with the processing or handling of highly hazardous chemicals.



Operating Procedures are established for the process relating to tasks to be performed, data to be recorded, operating conditions maintained, samples to be collected, and safety and health precautions to be taken. Operating procedures are reviewed, and updated if needed, on an annual basis.



Employees are trained to understand the nature and causes of the problems created by process operations and increase employee awareness and reactions to the hazards of the process.  Training also includes O&M procedures, health and safety, emergency  operations, and safe work practices.  Refresher training is provided annually.



Mechanical Integrity has been developed to assure the continued integrity of process equipment.  The program includes the identification of all equipment and instrumentation, written maintenance procedures, documentation of maintenance training, and documentation of inspections and testing. Mechanical Integrity Testing is conducted every five (5) years to verify suitability for continued operation per API-510 and the ASME Sec. VIII Div. 1 construction code.



An Incident Investigation has been developed to investigate incidents that occur in the facility including written investigations procedures.



Compliance Audits of the facility PSM/RMP program are conducted evaluated at least every three years and must include auditing maintenance records for the previous two years.



The Contractor Safety Program ensures that contractors hired to work in and around processes that involve highly hazardous chemicals have been screened by reviewing their safety performance records. Written procedures have been developed that also include training for contractors.



Pre-Startup Safety Review and Procedures are conducted as part of the "normal startup" operating procedure for each system.

Written procedures for conducting a pre-startup safety review have been developed and personnel have been trained in their use.



Hot Work authorization procedures are in place which reference and coordinate, as applicable, with lockout/tagout procedures, line breaking procedures, confined space entry procedures, and hot work permits.



The Management of Change Program monitors and controls all modifications to equipment, procedures, raw materials, and processing conditions.



Employees are encouraged and required to participate in the RMP/PSM process.  Their input is of critical importance and is required by regulation. All employees have access to information developed under the RMP/PSM Program.



Employees are trained to understand the safety and health hazards of the chemicals and processes in their work area that involve highly hazardous chemicals.  Additional training in operating procedures, safe work practices, emergency response and evacuation, and other areas pertinent to process safety and health are covered in the facility's training program.  Records of training are maintained.
